body:
What arguments are you passing Electron when you start it?

This type of error could occur if you started electron with a path to a executable file instead of a JavaScript or HTML file.

> In my case, it doesn’t work when run from a node app or when run without arguments.
> node electron

This is most likely the issue, you should just run `electron`. `node electron` tries to parse the `electron` executable as a JavaScript file which fails with the error you are seeing.

Ok. What do I have to change in my app to make it work?

In our app, when I do npm start… it fails as well.

From: Kevin Sawicki <notifications@github.com<mailto:notifications@github.com>>
Reply-To: electron/electron <reply@reply.github.com<mailto:reply@reply.github.com>>
Date: Monday, April 3, 2017 at 8:08 PM
To: electron/electron <electron@noreply.github.com<mailto:electron@noreply.github.com>>
Cc: Sam Costa <sam@sc.productions<mailto:sam@sc.productions>>, Author <author@noreply.github.com<mailto:author@noreply.github.com>>
Subject: Re: [electron/electron] Unexpected Token - Raspberry Pi 3/Raspbian (#9064)


In my case, it doesn’t work when run from a node app or when run without arguments.
node electron

This is most likely the issue, you should just run electron. node electron tries to parse the electron executable as a JavaScript file which fails with the error you are seeing.

—
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/9064#issuecomment-291332863>, or mute the thread<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AZjsGV2LaMjKKK3lC8Dx_Ng4Hy0vYjGKks5rsYoEgaJpZM4Muq03>.

> Ok. What do I have to change in my app to make it work?

Run `electron` with the path to your app's main JS file as the first argument, or use  https://github.com/electron-userland/electron-packager to package your app up and then just run the executable it generates.

That… doesn’t work either. I installed electron globally to make it easier:

Sudo npm install electron -g

Run:
Electron


No output occurs. Not the default output or anything. It just goes to a new line.


From: Kevin Sawicki [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: Monday, April 3, 2017 8:24 PM

Cc: Sam Costa <sam@sc.productions>; Author <author@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [electron/electron] Unexpected Token - Raspberry Pi 3/Raspbian (#9064)


Ok. What do I have to change in my app to make it work?

Run electron with the path to your app's main JS file as the first argument, or use https://github.com/electron-userland/electron-packager to package your app up and then just run the executable it generates.

Well, that didn’t work.

Electron, just running the command itself, it won’t run. I did a global install:


Electron

{3-5 seconds passes)

New line. No output.




I ran npm rebuild once, and it worked… and now I’m back to square one.


From: Kevin Sawicki [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: Monday, April 3, 2017 8:24 PM
To: electron/electron <electron@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Sam Costa <sam@sc.productions>; Author <author@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [electron/electron] Unexpected Token - Raspberry Pi 3/Raspbian (#9064)


Ok. What do I have to change in my app to make it work?

Run electron with the path to your app's main JS file as the first argument, or use https://github.com/electron-userland/electron-packager to package your app up and then just run the executable it generates.

> (function (exports, require, module, __filename, __dirname) { ^ELF

Closing this out, this looks like an issue where the electron executable was passed to node as a script to run and failed because it wasn't a JavaScript file.

`npm install electron` installs an `electron` command that can be used to launch apps via `electron /path/to/my/app`. You can run `electron -h` for more information.
